title: How to Use and Customize Tailwind CSS Typography Plugin
description: When developing a website that needs to display lengthy content, such as markdown-rendered text or HTML fetched from a CMS, considerable effort is...

children.value:
When developing a website that needs to display lengthy content, such as markdown-rendered text or HTML fetched from a CMS, considerable effort is required to make the text look beautiful and readable.
The Tailwind CSS typography plugin makes it very easy and quick to apply typography to your content.
Typography refers to the technique or art of making text look beautiful and readable by combining elements such as fonts, text sizes, line spacing, and margins.
Since Tailwind CSS installation is recommended differently for each environment, it is replaced with the

.
Here's how to install the plugin.
You can apply typography to the elements you want by combining the

props.code:

Lorem Ipsum has been the industry's standard dummy text ever since the 1500s, when an unknown printer took a galley of type and scrambled it to make a type specimen book.

When applying typography, the maximum width is limited to

to maintain readability of the content.
However, in production environments,  there are often many cases where you want to utilize all available width. In this case, you can use the
class to override the maximum width.

props.code: {{ markdown }}

children.value: The typography plugin allows you to specify styles by combining four types of modifiers:
: for adjusting typography size-related styles such as font size, line height, and margins.
: for handling gray-scale colors that goes well with text colors.
: for applying styles to specific HTML elements.
: for applying color inversion to text for dark mode.
Modifier classes are designed to be used with the multi-class modifier pattern and must be used in conjunction with the base
A design pattern that allows you to apply styles to elements by combining multiple classes. This pattern enables more flexible styling than using a single class.
When adjusting typography size-related styles, such as font size, line height, and margins, you can use size modifiers.
To illustrate, let's create an example based on hypothetical requirements:
font size for devices with a resolution below
font size for devices with a resolution of
is the default modifier, so it can be omitted.
The typography plugin comes with five pre-defined gray scale modifier classes suitable for body text.
Monotone refers to a combination of colors consisting of a single hue (gray, black, or white), while gray scale refers to a combination of colors consisting of various shades of gray.
Again, let's create an example based on hypothetical requirements:
Apply the slate color scheme as the default.
Apply the stone color scheme for devices with a resolution of
You can also use all the color modifiers provided by Tailwind CSS, but they are limited to link elements.
element on devices with a resolution below
element on devices with a resolution of
Element modifiers allow you to apply styles to individual HTML elements. Here's a list of supported element modifiers:
To illustrate, let's create an example based on hypothetical requirements:

props.code:
<article class="prose prose-h2:underline prose-h3:underline prose-img:rounded-lg prose-a:text-sky-500">
  {{ markdown }}
</article>

children.value: All colors in the typography plugin include a dark mode version. You can activate this by using the
Although you can achieve a high level of typography sophistication with the basic usage, what if:
You want to exclude typography styles from specific elements and use Tailwind CSS default styles.
You need customization because modifiers alone are insufficient to achieve the desired style.

class make element as  sandbox, isolating it from the influence of typography styles.
And, it's important to note that even if the
class is applied to elements within the
class, typography styles will not be applied.

props.code:

Lorem Ipsum has been the industry's standard dummy text ever since the 1500s, when an unknown printer took a galley of type and scrambled it to make a type specimen book.
element acts as a sandbox, preventing typography styles from being applied to self and any of its internal elements.
element also won't have typography styles applied for the reasons mentioned earlier.

The property keys written in the example match the modifiers we've learned earlier.
Therefore, to customize the elements you want, you can redefine them reference the browser's developer tools and the
style definition code of the typography plugin

props.code:
/** @type {import('tailwindcss').Config} */
module.exports = {
  theme: {
    extend: {
      typography: (theme) => ({
        DEFAULT: {},
        sm: {},
        base: {},
        lg: {},
        xl: {},
        '2xl': {},
        slate: {},
        gray: {},
        zinc: {},
        neutral: {},
        stone: {},
        red: {},
        orange: {},
        amber: {},
        yellow: {},
        lime: {},
        green: {},
        emerald: {},
        teal: {},
        cyan: {},
        sky: {},
        blue: {},
        indigo: {},
        violet: {},
        purple: {},
        fuchsia: {},
        pink: {},
        rose: {},
        invert: {},
      }),
    },
  },
  plugins: [
    require('@tailwindcss/typography'),
    // ...
  ],
}

children.value: Let's create an example based on hypothetical requirements:
Currently, the table element occupies the entire available width with
. We want to change this to use only the width of the content by setting it to
We want to standardize the font weight of h1, h2, h3, and h4 elements to
to prevent header overlap when navigating with internal links.
We'll change the default typography font color to black and to white in dark mode.

Adding a new modifier is the same process as overriding existing modifiers, with the difference being that you add the modifier not built into the plugin as a property key.
Let's add a modifier called
, which handles colors, as an example.
In the previous example, we only utilized CSS variables built into the plugin to compose styles, so there was no need to input additional values for the

property.
This time, let's add a new property that is not built into the plugin.
When adding a new CSS variable like this, it must be added in the inversion modifier.
When using the created brand modifier, it should be used as

html .default .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-default);background: var(--shiki-default-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-default-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-default-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-default-text-decoration);}html .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-default);background: var(--shiki-default-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-default-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-default-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-default-text-decoration);}html .dark .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-dark);background: var(--shiki-dark-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-dark-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-dark-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-dark-text-decoration);}html.dark .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-dark);background: var(--shiki-dark-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-dark-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-dark-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-dark-text-decoration);}
